description: From Middle English massif, from Middle French massif. The Irish sense is possibly derived from Irish mas (“fine, handsome”).

adjectives.description: massive (comparative more massive, superlative most massive)

entries.meaning: Very large in size or extent.
examples: Compared to its counterparts from World War II, the Abrams main battle tank is truly massive.

entries.meaning: Very large or bulky and heavy and solid.
examples: A massive comet or asteroid appears to have ended the era of the dinosaurs.

entries.meaning: (informal) To a very great extent; total, utter.
examples: Notwithstanding Catherine's assurances, I was apprehensive about meeting Denys, worried that I would come off as a massive idiot  […]

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Of particularly exceptional quality or value; awesome.
examples: Did you see Colbert last night? He was massive!
Your dress is massive, love. Where did you get it?

entries.meaning: (medicine) Affecting a large portion of the body, or severe.
(physics, of a particle) Having any mass.
examples: Some bosons are massive while others are massless.

entries.meaning: (mineralogy) Not having an obvious crystalline structure.
(mineralogy) A homogeneous mass of rock, not layered and without an obvious crystal structure.
(MLE, slang) A group of people from a locality, or sharing a collective aim, interest, etc.
examples: Big up to the Croydon massive!
